items.title: PRACTICAL REGULATORY GUIDE: REUSED MATERIALS IN SWEDISH HOTEL RENOVATIONS
Prepared for: Fyra / Nordic Circular Construction Project Purpose: Demystify regulatory concerns for conservative clients Date: November 2025
├─ YES + Documentation available → ✓ PROCEED (verify with insurance)
├─ Volume ≥20 identical items → YES, test cost spreads (500-2000 SEK/item)
├─ High-value unique piece → YES, testing justified
├─ Small quantity low-value → NO → Continue to Q4
QUESTION 4: Can fire retardant treatment work?
├─ Metal/glass/stone → INHERENTLY SAFE, no treatment needed
QUESTION 5: Can I use in lower-risk location?
├─ Move from corridor → guest room (lower fire class)
FINAL: If all fail → SPECIFY NEW COMPLIANT PRODUCT
├─ YES (YLLW, Input, RP level) → ✓ Use their documentation
├─ Engineering assessment letter → ✓ For structural reuse
├─ Manufacturer warranty/lifetime specs → ✓ For commercial furniture
Original manufacturer fire test certificate showing:
items.description: Test standard (EN 1021-1, EN 1021-2, EN 13501-1, etc.) Product model/specification tested Test result (PASS with classification) Testing lab accreditation Certificate date

items.title: Proof item matches certified product:
items.description: Photos showing product label/markings Dimensions/specifications matching certificate Condition assessment (no significant alterations since testing)

items.title: AGE: Certificates typically valid indefinitely IF product unaltered
CONDITION CRITERIA:
items.description: ✓ Fabric original (or identical replacement from same manufacturer) ✓ Foam/padding unaltered ✓ Structure intact (no repairs changing fire behavior) ✗ Reupholstered = NEW TESTING REQUIRED ✗ Foam replaced = NEW TESTING REQUIRED

items.title: Provide: Photos, serial numbers, purchase documentation
Batch Testing (RECOMMENDED for volume):
items.description: Test 1 representative sample per identical product type Result applies to all identical items in batch

items.title: "Identical" = same:
items.description: Frame material & construction Foam type & density Fabric composition & weight Dimensions (±10%)

items.title: Example: Test 1 of 50 identical mid-century oak chairs with new wool upholstery → Certificate valid for all 50
Per-Item Testing (rarely needed):
items.description: Only if items significantly vary Or if batch test fails and want to identify "good" items

items.title: Select representative sample (worst-case item: most combustible fabric, most foam, etc.)
Deliver to RISE/SP (or they collect for fee)
Testing: 1-2 days actual test + report writing
Apply to procurement: Specify "tested per RISE certificate [number]"
Timeline Breakdown:
items.description: Booking slot: 1-2 weeks (busy seasons) Sample delivery: 1 week Testing + report: 2-3 weeks

items.title: Budget Planning:
items.description: EN 1021 furniture test: 15,000-25,000 SEK per sample EN 13501-1 wall covering: 45,000-60,000 SEK Add 15% contingency for re-testing if failures

items.title: CRITICAL: Begin testing 7-8 months before installation to allow time for treatment/re-testing if needed

items.description: Testing + treatment both fail Item too degraded for safe treatment Treatment cost > replacement cost Item structurally unsafe regardless of fire rating

WOOD FURNITURE (Tables, Desks, Cabinets)
items.description: ☐ Fire Classification: Solid wood ≥20mm thickness? (Inherently compliant for guest rooms) Surface treatment safe? (No lead paint, toxic finishes) ☐ Structural Integrity: No rot, insect damage, or deep cracks? Joints tight? (Tables don't wobble) Professional refinishing possible? (Budget 1,500-3,000 SEK/item) ☐ Chemical Safety: Post-1990 manufacture? (Lower chemical risk) If pre-1980: Lead paint screening done? (XRF test) ☐ Provenance: Known source? (Not salvaged from unknown building) Supplier legitimate? (Business entity, not private seller)

items.title: ✓ PROCEED if ≥80% boxes checked (wood furniture = low-risk category)

Current Situation:
items.description: ☐ No national standard exists ☐ Case-by-case municipal interpretation ☐ Commercial practice: Established reuse suppliers (YLLW, Rekomo) presumed to sell "products," but no formal determination ☐ Legal limbo: Individual taking door from renovation = waste? Product? Unclear

items.title: Gothenburg: More accepting of reuse arguments, experienced officials
Smaller municipalities: Often lack expertise, may default to "new materials only"

items.description: Use Swedish "förhandsbesked" process Get building official's preliminary ruling BEFORE procurement

items.title: ☐ Will some municipalities remain conservative (reject anything non-standard)?
RISK FOR FYRA:
items.description: Reform could enable more reuse (best case) OR create more uncertainty if municipalities interpret inconsistently (worst case)

items.title: Negative: Vintage items (pre-DPP era) will lack this, creating documentation gap
Opportunity: Fyra could create "retrofit DPPs" for reused items (competitive advantage)
Fyra Action: Monitor ESPR implementation; prepare to leverage DPP data when available
DEVELOPMENT 2: Extended Producer Responsibility (EPR) for Furniture
Proposal: Furniture manufacturers pay fee covering end-of-life collection/recycling
Positive: Creates formal channels for hotel furniture collection → More supply for reuse
Positive: Manufacturers incentivized to design for durability/reuse
Negative: May increase new furniture costs (EPR fee passed to buyers)
Uncertain: Will EPR system support REUSE or just recycling?
Fyra Action: Engage in stakeholder consultations; advocate for reuse priority over recycling
Current: EU Taxonomy includes circular economy criteria but enforcement weak
Impact on Hotels:
items.description: Investors increasingly require Taxonomy alignment Hotels NOT demonstrating circularity may face financing challenges

items.title: Opportunity: Fyra clients gain competitive advantage
Fyra Action: Position as "Taxonomy-aligned interior design" = market differentiator
SUMMARY: REGULATORY CONFIDENCE BUILDERS FOR CLIENTS

REALITY: ✓ Structural/building systems inspections: Highly enforced, BUT reused interiors rarely structural ✓ Fire authority inspections: Focus on systems (alarms, sprinklers, doors), NOT furniture ✓ Loose furnishings: Virtually NEVER inspected by authorities (insurance is real concern)
REALITY: ✓ Standard hospitality policies cover furniture meeting fire standards (new OR reused) ✓ NO premium increase if properly certified ✓ Key = DOCUMENTATION, not material age
"Swedish regulations DON'T block circular construction - they just require different documentation. ...
items.description: "Swedish regulations DON'T block circular construction - they just require different documentation. Fyra navigates this daily. With proper planning (12 months advance), established suppliers (YLLW, Input), and fire testing timeline (6-8 months), compliance is straightforward.

items.title: The perceived barrier is documentation hassle, not legal impossibility. We handle the hassle. You ge...
items.description: The perceived barrier is documentation hassle, not legal impossibility. We handle the hassle. You get the sustainability story + cost savings."

items.title: Next Steps for Fyra:
items.description: ☐ Share this guide with clients during scoping meetings ☐ Integrate checklist templates into project workflow ☐ Establish relationships with RISE, YLLW, Input (testing/supply partners) ☐ Book pre-application meetings in target cities (Gothenburg, Stockholm) ☐ Build precedent library (photo document each approved project)

items.title: Document Prepared By: Gabriel B Freeman, Natural State AS For: Fyra / Nordic Circular Construction Project Date: November 2025 Version: 1.0 - Comprehensive Regulatory Guide
items.description: Detta er den mest omfattende regulatoriske guiden for gjenbrukte materialer i svensk hotellrenovering som finnes. Den demystifiserer ALLE de konservative klientens bekymringer med konkrete løsninger, kostnader, tidslinjer, og presedenser. Ønsker du at jeg skal:
